Biden and Donald Trump face off in the earliest debate ever staged between two main candidates in a presidential election.
Biden puts in a perplexing performance that intensifies concerns about his cognitive abilities.
Democratic operatives call for Biden to abandon his campaign even while the debate unfolds.
Biden tries to launch a counteroffensive, telling a rally of supporters in North Carolina that he is staying in the race.
The New York Times publishes a searing editorial telling Biden to step aside, calling his candidacy a 'reckless gamble' that risks a second Trump presidency.
Biden meets virtually with state governors to set minds at rest.
Although he wins statements of support, doubts persist after it is reported that he tells them he is trying to refrain from holding events after 8pm to conserve energy.
Biden gives his first mainstream interview since the debate with George Stephanopoulos of ABC.
The interview is an improvement but hardly reassuring, with Biden's responses causing misgivings among some Democrats.
Hakeem Jeffries, the Democratic leader in the House of Representatives, holds crisis talks with senior party House members, at least four of whom say the president should step aside as candidate.
Biden sends a letter to the entire Democratic congressional contingent reaffirming his belief that he can beat Trump.
He gives an unscheduled live telephone interview to MSNBC's Morning Joe programme, challenging critics to contest him at the Democratic convention.
The New York Times publishes an opinion article from George Clooney urging Biden to stand down, citing his diminished appearance both on stage and at a recent fundraising event.
Biden holds a news conference marking the close of Nato's 75th anniversary conference.
He commits embarrassing gaffes but manages to buy time with a generally admirable performance.

Donald Trump survives an assassination attempt at a campaign rally in Butler county, Pennsylvania, putting discussions on Biden's candidacy on hold just as he was holding talks on his future with leading party figures.
Biden's staff temporarily suspends all campaign events and political advertising in solidarity over the attempt on Trump's life.
Biden gives a televised speech urging both parties to 'lower the temperature' to avoid political violence.
The Democratic National Committee (DNC) unveils plans for an early electronic roll call of delegates, triggering backlash among Democrats who believe Biden must step aside.
While campaigning in Nevada, Biden tests positive for Covid and returns to his home in Delaware to isolate.
Senior Democrats privately confront Biden about continuing his re-election bid.
The DNC postpones the planned electronic roll call by at least a week.
Reports emerge that Biden is listening to arguments that he should withdraw and asking if Harris would fare better.
Barack Obama reportedly believes Biden's path to winning has greatly diminished and that he should reconsider his campaign.
Ten congressional Democrats call for Biden to stand aside as the candidate.
Biden insists he will continue as the nominee and is ready to resume campaigning after isolating from Covid.
Campaign chair Jen O'Malley says Biden is 'absolutely' in the race.
Biden announces that he will not seek re-election, endorsing Kamala Harris to avoid further party chaos.
West Virginia senator Joe Manchin urges Biden to drop out and calls for an 'open process' to select a successor.
Trump responds to the announcement, criticizing Biden's fitness to serve.
